resources.string: Do you know that Atoms mode everything in this world? Even you and me

Atoms like to have just the right amount of electrons to be happy Atoms are nice and help each other out! So when there are some atoms have too many, while other atoms don\'t have enough, they will share electrons with each other.
When Atoms help each other we called this chemical bond And there are two main types of chemical bonds Covalent and Ionic

Covalent Bond happen when both atoms are missing electrons For example, an oxygen atom is missing two electrons and a hydrogen atom is missing one These atoms will team up and share electrons, this bond will give us H2O which is water!

string-array.name: C2L3S4E1M
string-array.item: One atom missing electrons and another one have extra electrons

resources.string: Ionic Bonds happen when one atom missing electrons and another one have extra electrons For example, a sodium atom has one extra electron. A chlorine atom is missing one electron. The sodium atom will give its extra electron to the chlorine atom, then we will have NaCl or salt
When two or more atoms bond, they make an entirely new substance called a compound. This substance doesn\'t have the same characteristics as the atoms it was made with.
A chemical equation is a way to represent a chemical reaction using element symbols. Chemical equations have two sides: the reactant side and the product side.
There is only one atom of each element in the equation, unless the element has a coefficient or a subscript with it.

resources.string: A subscript tells how many atoms of that element there are. The coefficients are multiplied by every element or its subscript to determine the number of atoms.

So how do we balance an equation? To start, we count the number of atoms of each element. Once we know the total number of atoms of each element, we can change or add coefficients to make the sides balance. Important: We can NEVER change or add subscripts!

resources.string: We can use the pH Scale to measure how basic (alkaline) or acidic things are.

Have you ever tasted a lemon and puckered up? Lemons have that puckery taste because they\'re acidic, just like vinegar and some other foods. \n Scientists use the pH scale to describe whether something is acidic or basic. Basic is the opposite of acidic.
The pH scale goes from 0 to 14: 0 is the most acidic and 14 is the most basic, or alkaline. \n Plain water is right in the middle of the scale with a pH of 7. This is called a neutral pH
